HSBC – NORTH AMERICA (U.S.) PENSION PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
1. General Description of the Plan
General
The HSBC – North America (U.S.) Pension Plan (the “Plan”) is a noncontributory defined benefit pension plan sponsored by
HSBC North America Holdings Inc. (“HNAH” or the “Plan Sponsor”). The Plan is subject to the requirements of the Employee
Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended (“ERISA”). The assets of the Plan at December 31, 2024 and 2023 were held
in the HSBC – North America (U.S.) Pension Trust (the “Trust”). The Northern Trust Company (the “Trustee” or "Northern Trust")
serves as trustee for the Trust. The plan administrator for the Plan is the HSBC – North America (U.S.) Benefits Administrative
Committee (“Administrative Committee”), which is responsible for administering the plan and complying with all ERISA reporting
and disclosure laws applicable to the Plan. The Administrative Committee has complete discretionary authority to interpret, apply,
and administer the terms of the Plan and to determine eligibility for benefits and the amount of any benefits under the Plan.
The Plan’s purpose is to provide retirement income to eligible employees of participating affiliated companies of HNAH. The
official plan document for the Plan as in effect for the Plan as amended contains all provisions of the Plan and is used to determine
how the Plan operates, what benefits are paid, and who is eligible to receive them. If there is any conflict between this description
and the official plan document (including amendments) for the Plan, the official plan document will govern. The Investment
Committee, as defined in Note 2, is responsible for determining the appropriateness of the Plan's investment offerings and
monitoring investment performance.
Eligibility
There are three general groups of participants: cash balance, legacy HSBC Bank (USA), N.A. (“HBUS”) and legacy Household
International, Inc. (“Household”):
• Cash balance participants include any eligible employee who became an employee of a participating affiliate of
HNAH on or after January 1, 2005 and before January 1, 2013, any eligible employee who became an employee
of Household or a participating affiliate for the first time between January 1, 2000 and December 31, 2004 and
any eligible employee who became an employee of HBUS or a participating affiliate for the first time between
January 1, 1997 and December 31, 2004. In addition, cash balance participants include prior participants in the
legacy HBUS and legacy Household formulas of the Plan who were employed by a participating affiliate of
HNAH on or after January 1, 2011.
◦ An eligible employee who becomes an employee for the first time on or after January 1, 2005 shall
become a participant in the cash balance formula on the first day of the month after the employee has
attained age 21 and completed one year of eligibility service provided that the employee is an eligible
employee on such date.
◦ An employee hired by Household or a participating affiliate between January 1, 2000 and December 31,
2004 shall become a participant in the cash balance formula on the first day of the month after the
employee has attained age 21 and completed one year of eligibility service provided that the employee is
an eligible employee on such date. An employee hired by Household or a participating affiliate before
January 1, 2000 shall only become a cash balance participant if they were employed by a participating
affiliate of HNAH on or after January 1, 2011.
◦ An employee hired by HBUS or a participating affiliate between January 1, 1997 and December 31, 2004
shall become a participant in the cash balance formula on the later of (1) January 1, 2005 provided that
the employee is an eligible employee on such date, or (2) the first day of the month after the employee
has attained age 21 and completed one year of eligibility service provided that the employee is an eligible
employee on such date. An employee hired by HBUS or a participating affiliate before January 1, 1997
shall only become a participant in the cash balance formula if they were employed by a participating
affiliate of HNAH on or after January 1, 2011.
• An employee hired by Household or a participating affiliate before January 1, 2000 shall become a participant in
the legacy Household formula on the date the employee has attained age 21 and completed one year of eligibility
service provided that the employee is an eligible employee on such date. These employees may also become
participants in the cash balance formula, but only if they were employed by a participating affiliate of HNAH on
or after January 1, 2011.
666

HSBC – NORTH AMERICA (U.S.) PENSION PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
1. General Description of the Plan (continued)
• An employee hired by HBUS or a participating affiliate before January 1, 1997 shall become a participant in the
legacy HBUS formula on the January 1st or July 1st coincident with or next following the date the employee has
attained age 21 and completed one year of eligibility service provided that the employee is an eligible employee
on such January 1st or July 1st. These employees may also become participants in the cash balance formula, but
only if they were employed by a participating affiliate of HNAH on or after January 1, 2011.
Vesting
• A participant in the cash balance formula shall be fully vested in the employees’ accrued benefit upon the
completion of 3 years of vesting service. Additionally, a participant who was an employee on December 31, 2012,
or who was not an employee on December 31, 2012, but becomes an employee for any length of time after
December 31, 2012, shall be deemed to be fully vested in the employees’ accrued benefit.
• A participant in the legacy Household formula shall be fully vested in the employees’ accrued benefit upon the
completion of 3 years of vesting service if the date of the participant’s last hour of service is on or after January 1,
2000; 5 years of vesting service if such date is on or after January 1, 1989 but before January 1, 2000; and 10
years of vesting service if such date is before January 1, 1989.
• A HBUS Plan Participant shall be fully vested in the employees’ accrued benefit upon the completion of 3 years
of vesting service if the date of Participant’s last hour of service is on or after January 1, 2005; 5 years of vesting
service if such date is on or after January 1, 1989 but before January 1, 2005; and 10 years of vesting service if
such date is before January 1, 1989.
• In October 2009, the Plan Sponsor voluntarily chose to recognize a partial termination of the Plan for the
2007-2009 plan years. The recognition of the partial termination was then extended to include the 2010-2012 plan
years. Accordingly, all plan participants whose employment was terminated with affiliated companies of HNAH
during the 2007-2012 plan years became fully vested in their accrued pension benefit, notwithstanding the vesting
requirements.
Pension Benefit
The Plan provides separate benefit formulas for the three mutually exclusive groups of Participants:
• Participants in the cash balance formula have their benefits determined under a cash balance formula (Cash
Balance Component) covering later hires of all participating employers.
• Participants in the legacy Household formula have their benefits determined under a fractional accrual, final
average pay formula (HI-Final Pay Component) which covers earlier hires of Household or a participating
affiliate.
• Participants in the legacy HBUS formula have their benefits determined under a unit credit, final average pay
formula, (HBUS Plan Component) which covers earlier hires of HBUS or a participating affiliate.
All future benefit accruals of legacy HI-Final Pay Component and HBUS Plan Component participants ceased effective January 1,
2011. Any service or pay earned by such participants after December 31, 2010 is not used in benefit calculations under the final
average pay components. However, continued employment with a participating affiliate of HNAH will maintain a participant’s
eligibility to reach age and service milestones for early retirement subsidies and features which may be available under the particular
component. Accruals to all eligible plan participants, including participants who had accrued a benefit under a legacy final average
pay formula component under the Plan, were provided under the Cash Balance Component from January 1, 2010 until December
31, 2012. In July 2012, the Board of Directors of the Plan Sponsor approved a plan to cease all future benefit accruals of Cash
Balance Component participants effective January 1, 2013. Pay based credits for such participants ceased after December 31, 2012.
Interest rate credits will continue to be credited to existing cash balance accounts until the account is distributed.
Death and disability benefits, if any, vary according to the group for which the participant is eligible.

HSBC – NORTH AMERICA (U.S.) PENSION PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
1. General Description of the Plan (continued)
For 2024, the Plan was amended to increase the automatic cash-out limit from $5,000 to $7,000. For 2023, the Plan was amended to:
• Recognize Tribal Government Domestic Relations Orders;
• Revise how recoupments of overpayments operate pursuant to retirement legislation, such that the Administrative
Committee may seek to recover the overpayment from such person, offset the amount of the overpayment against
future payments to such person, or not seek to recover or offset the amount, as the Administrative Committee shall
determine in its discretion; and
• Increase the age at which required minimum distributions commence from age 72 to age 73.

HSBC – NORTH AMERICA (U.S.) PENSION PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
2. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Basis of Accounting
The accounts of the Plan are maintained on the accrual basis of accounting in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting
principles (“U.S. GAAP”).
Use of Estimates
The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions
that materially affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, and changes therein; disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities;
and the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits at the date of the financial statements, and changes therein. Actual
results could differ from those estimates.
Investment Valuation and Income Recognition
Security transactions are recognized on a trade date basis. Interest income is recorded on the accrual basis. Dividends are recorded
on the ex-dividend date.
Investments of the Plan are included in the statements of net assets available for benefits at fair value. Fair value is the price that
would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the
measurement date. Fair value is based on market quotations, if available. With respect to the participation in collective trusts, fair
value is based on the NAV of the collective trusts. The Plan's Investment Committee determines the Plan's valuation policies
utilizing information provided by its investment advisors and custodian.
Net realized appreciation/(depreciation) of investments is the difference between the selling price of an investment and the cost of
that investment or the settlement value upon termination of the derivative contract. The change in unrealized appreciation/
(depreciation) of investments is the difference between the fair value of an investment or derivative contract at the end of the plan
year and the fair value of the same investment or derivative contract at the beginning of the plan year or at its acquisition date if
acquired during the plan year.
Net realized appreciation/(depreciation) on derivatives consists of the settlement value upon termination of the derivative contracts.
The change in unrealized appreciation/(depreciation) of derivatives is the difference between the fair value of the derivative at the
end of the plan year and the fair value of the same derivative at the beginning of the plan year or on the trade date if the derivative
contract is executed during the plan year.
Funding Policy
The HSBC – North America (U.S.) Investment Committee (“Investment Committee”) is responsible for developing and
implementing investment and funding policies for the Plan. Contributions to the Plan are determined with reference to actuarial
determinations of funding requirements, which include assumptions regarding rates of return on investments, salary and benefit
increases, mortality rates and other factors, as well as consideration of ERISA funding requirements. The Investment Committee has
adopted a pension funding policy that requires the Plan Sponsor and participating affiliates to annually contribute the greatest of:
• The minimum contribution required under ERISA guidelines;
• An amount necessary to ensure the ratio of the Plan’s assets at the end of the year as compared to the Plan’s
accrued benefit obligation, as determined under Pension Protection Act, is equal to or greater than 90 percent; or
• Pension expense for the year as determined under current accounting guidance.
The Plan has met the minimum funding requirements of ERISA for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023.
Accumulated Plan Benefits
Accumulated plan benefits are those future periodic payments, including lump-sum distributions, that are attributable under the
Plan’s provisions for services rendered by the employees to the valuation date. Accumulated plan benefits include benefits expected
to be paid to (a) retired or terminated employees or their beneficiaries, (b) beneficiaries of employees who have died and (c) present
employees or their beneficiaries upon retirement or termination based upon the current level of benefits as specified in the official
Plan agreement.
999

HSBC – NORTH AMERICA (U.S.) PENSION PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
2. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (continued)
Actuaries determine the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits, which is the amount that results from applying
actuarial assumptions to adjust the accumulated plan benefits for the time value of money (through discounts for interest) and the
probability of payment (by means of decrements such as for death, withdrawal or retirement) between the valuation date and the
expected date of payment. See Note 5 for additional information.
Payment of Benefits
Benefit payments to participants are recorded upon distribution.
Forfeitures
The Plan provides that amounts arising upon a participant’s termination of service without a vested interest and any other forfeiture
under the Plan shall be taken into account in determining the contributions required each year from the Plan Sponsor to the Trust to
meet statutory minimum funding requirements. Forfeitures are not applied to increase the benefits that any Participant would
otherwise receive under the Plan.
Administrative Expenses
Most administrative expenses are paid by the Plan, including, but not limited to, third-party administration and record keeping,
trustee, investment management, investment advisory, consulting, legal and actuarial expenses.
3. Plan Termination
The Plan Sponsor reserves the right to amend, suspend or terminate the Plan and the benefits provided to the extent permitted by
law, in whole or in part, at any time and for any reason. The Plan can be amended only by written instrument executed as directed
by the Board of Directors of HNAH or by certain designated officers of HNAH. Upon termination of the Plan, a participant's benefit
is non-forfeitable to the extent it was both accrued and funded on the date of such termination.
In the event the Plan is terminated, the funds and other property held under any trust which is part of the Plan, net of administration
and liquidation expenses, shall be allocated to vested active participants, retirees or their beneficiaries, in accordance with Section
4044 of ERISA, to the extent of the sufficiency of such funds and other property. The funds and property remaining after such
allocation, if any, shall be paid or delivered to the Plan Sponsor.
The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (“PBGC”), a federal insurance agency, insures benefits under the Plan. If the Plan should
end without sufficient assets to pay all benefits, the PBGC will pay such benefits, subject to the limits set by law. Generally, the
PBGC guarantees most vested normal retirement benefits, early retirement benefits and certain disability and survivor pensions.
However, the PBGC does not guarantee all types of benefits under covered plans, and the amount of benefit protection is subject to
certain limitations.
The PBGC guarantees vested benefits at the level in effect on the date of plan termination. However, if a plan has been in effect for
less than five years before it terminates, or if benefits have been increased within five years before plan termination, the whole
amount of the plan’s vested benefits or the benefit increase may not be guaranteed. In addition, there is a limit on the amount of
monthly benefits that the PBGC guarantees which is adjusted periodically.

7. Tax Status of the Plan
The Plan has received a favorable determination letter dated October 27, 2017 from the Internal Revenue Service (“IRS”)
confirming the Plan’s continuing tax-qualified status under the Internal Revenue Code (the “Code”). In 2017, the IRS ended the
determination letter cycle program for individual designed plans. Accordingly, absent special circumstances outlined by IRS
guidance, the Plan will not be receiving determination letters going forward. Although the Plan has been amended since applying
for the October 27, 2017 determination letter, the Plan’s administrator and the Plan’s Counsel believe that the Plan is designed and
is currently being operated in compliance with applicable requirements of the Code.
U.S. generally accepted accounting principles require plan management to evaluate tax positions taken by the Plan and recognize a
tax liability (or asset) if the Plan has taken an uncertain position that more likely than not would not be sustained upon examination
by the IRS. The plan administrator has analyzed the tax positions taken by the Plan, and has concluded that as of December 31,
2024 and 2023, there are no uncertain positions taken or expected to be taken that would require recognition of a liability (or asset)
or disclosure in the financial statements. The Plan is subject to routine audits by taxing jurisdictions; however, there are currently no
audits for any tax periods in progress.
8. Party-In-Interest Transactions
Transactions resulting in Plan assets being transferred to or used by a related party are prohibited under ERISA and/or the Code
unless a specific exemption applies. The plan engages in numerous transactions and third party service relationships that are subject
to those prohibited transaction rules. For example, the plan participates in a securities lending program managed by the custodian
Northern Trust. These transactions and service relationships are generally designed (a) to avoid prohibited transactions for which
there are no exemptions (e.g., self-dealing), and (b) where exemptions are available, to utilize those exemptions from the prohibited
transaction rules.
9. Securities Lending
The Plan participates in the Northern Trust securities lending program wherein securities are lent to certain securities dealers in
exchange for collateral at 102% of the value of the securities lent. The Plan retains a beneficial interest in the collateral held. Income
earned on lending activity is allocated to the Plan as stipulated in the securities lending agreement and is included in net investment
income in the statements of changes in net assets available for benefits for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023,
respectively. Types of securities being lent in this program include common stocks, U.S. government securities, and corporate
bonds, and had a fair value of $397,711 thousand and $548,937 thousand secured by cash collateral of $406,497 thousand and
$561,722 thousand as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively. The cash collateral obligation is presented as payable under
securities lending agreements. In addition, securities with a market value of $179,841 thousand and $107,645 thousand were
secured by non-cash collateral of $185,017 thousand and $110,627 thousand as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively. The
securities lending amounts are subject to an enforceable master netting arrangement that management has elected to not offset on the
statements of net assets available for benefits.
10. Risks and Uncertainties
The Plan invests in various investment securities. Investment securities are exposed to various risks such as interest rate, market,
counterparty, securities lending and credit risks. Due to the level of risk associated with certain investment securities, it is at least
reasonably possible that changes in the values of investment securities will occur in the near term and that such change could
materially affect the amounts reported in the statements of net assets available for benefits.
Plan contributions are made and the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits are reported based on certain assumptions
pertaining to interest rates, inflation rates and employee demographics, all of which are subject to change. Due to uncertainties
inherent in the estimations and assumptions process, it is at least reasonably possible that changes in these estimates and
assumptions in the near term would be material to the financial statements.

11. Derivative Financial Instruments
The Plan uses interest rate swaps, futures, credit default swaps and swaptions to manage risk of the Plan’s investment portfolio.
Interest rate swaps are contractual agreements between two counterparties for the exchange of periodic interest payments generally
based on a notional amount and agreed-upon fixed or floating rates. Interest rate futures are contracts between the buyer and seller
agreeing to the future delivery of any interest-bearing asset. The Plan also utilizes credit default swaps to manage the credit risk on
certain underlying debt. Credit default swaps entail the seller of the swaps receiving payments from the buyer and guaranteeing
payment of the debt should the debtor default. Additionally, the Plan utilizes swaptions to manage interest rate risk, which grant the
owner the right but not the obligation to enter into an underlying swap. All derivatives are recognized on the statements of net assets
available for benefits at their fair value. Changes in the fair value of the derivatives are recorded as net appreciation/(depreciation) in
fair value of investments and derivatives on the statements of changes in net assets available for benefits.

12. Fair Value Measurements
Accounting principles related to fair value measurements provide a framework for measuring fair value and focuses on an exit price
in the principal (or alternatively, the most advantageous) market accessible in an orderly transaction between willing market
participants (the “Fair Value Framework”). The Fair Value Framework establishes a three-tiered fair value hierarchy with Level 1
representing quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities. Fair values determined by Level 2 inputs
are inputs that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly. Level 2 inputs include quoted prices for similar
assets or liabilities in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in markets that are not active, and
inputs other than quoted prices that are observable for the asset or liability, such as interest rates and yield curves that are observable
at commonly quoted intervals. Level 3 inputs are unobservable inputs for the asset or liability and include situations where there is
little, if any, market activity for the asset or liability. Transfers between leveling categories are recognized at the end of each
reporting period.

12. Fair Value Measurements (continued)
Valuation Techniques for Plan Assets
The following is a description of valuation methodologies used for significant categories of Plan assets recorded at fair value.
Securities: Fair value of securities is generally determined by a third party valuation source. The pricing services generally source
fair value measurements from quoted market prices and if not available, the security is valued based on quotes from similar
securities using broker quotes and other information obtained from dealers and market participants. For securities which do not trade
in active markets, such as fixed income securities, the pricing services generally utilize various pricing applications, including
models, to measure fair value. The pricing applications are based on market convention and use inputs that are derived principally
from or corroborated by observable market data by correlation or other means. The following summarizes the valuation
methodology used for the major security types of the pension plan assets:
• Cash and short-term investments – These investments consist of cash and a fund that invests in highly-liquid,
actively traded securities with durations of less than 12 months.
• Common Stock and Preferred Stock – Since most of the securities are transacted in active markets, fair value
measurements are determined based on quoted prices for the identical security.
• Government Securities – As these securities transact in an active market, the pricing services source fair value
measurements from quoted prices for the identical security or quoted prices for similar securities with adjustments
as necessary made using observable inputs which are market corroborated. For securities not actively traded,
credit spreads are obtained from the new issue market, secondary trading levels and dealer quotes. For securities
with early redemption features, an option adjusted spread (“OAS”) model is incorporated to adjust the spreads
determined above. Additionally, the pricing services will survey the broker/dealer community to obtain relevant
trade data including benchmark quotes and updated spreads.
• Asset-backed securities – The leveling of these securities considers the credit quality of the individual security.
For certain government sponsored mortgage-backed securities which transact in an active market, the pricing
services source fair value measurements from quoted prices for the identical security or quoted prices for similar
securities with adjustments as necessary being made using observable inputs which are market corroborated. For
government sponsored mortgage-backed securities which do not transact in an active market, fair value is
determined using discounted cash flow models and inputs related to interest rates, prepayment speeds, loss curves
and market discount rates that would be required by investors in the current market given the specific
characteristics and inherent credit risk of the underlying collateral.
• Corporate bonds – For non-callable corporate securities, a credit spread scale is created for each issuer. These
spreads are then added to the equivalent maturity U.S. Treasury yield to determine current pricing. Credit spreads
are obtained from the new issue market, secondary trading levels and dealer quotes. For securities with early
redemption features, an option adjusted spread “OAS” model is incorporated to adjust the spreads determined
above. Additionally, the pricing services will survey the broker/dealer community to obtain relevant trade data
including benchmark quotes and updated spreads.
111999

HSBC – NORTH AMERICA (U.S.) PENSION PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
12. Fair Value Measurements (continued)
• Derivatives – Derivatives are recorded at fair value. Derivatives traded on an exchange are valued using quoted
prices. OTC derivatives, which comprise a majority of derivative contract positions, are valued using valuation
techniques. The fair value for the majority of derivative instruments are determined based on internally developed
models that utilize independently-sourced market parameters, including interest rate yield curves, option
volatilities, and currency rates. For complex or long-dated derivative products where market data is not available,
fair value may be affected by the choice of valuation model and the underlying assumptions about, among other
things, the timing of cash flows and credit spreads. The fair values of certain structured derivative products are
sensitive to unobservable inputs such as default correlations and volatilities. These estimates are susceptible to
significant change in future periods as market conditions change. Significant inputs related to derivative classes
are broken down as follows:
◦ Credit Derivatives – Use credit default curves and recovery rates which are generally provided by broker
quotes and various pricing services. Certain credit derivatives may also use correlation inputs in their
model valuation.
◦ Interest Rate Derivatives – Swaps use interest rate curves based on currency that are actively quoted by
brokers and other pricing services. Options will also use volatility inputs which are also quoted in the
broker market.
• Investments measured at net asset value - Certain of these investments consist of common stock funds and a
limited partnership which permit investors to redeem their ownership interests back to the issuer based on the
reported net asset value (“NAV”) per share. The NAV, as provided by the third party managers, is used as a
practical expedient to estimate fair value. The NAV is based on the fair value of the underlying investments held
by the fund/limited partnership less its liabilities. The common stock funds can be redeemed daily and/or weekly
with no redemption restrictions or unfunded commitments. The limited partnership can be redeemed bi-monthly
with no redemption restrictions or unfunded commitments. The remaining investments in this category consist of
non-exchange traded investments in fixed income and leveraged loan/high yield securities funds. The funds permit
investors to redeem their ownership interests from the issuer based on the reported NAV per share. Fixed income
funds can be redeemed daily and/or monthly and the leveraged loan/high yield securities fund can be redeemed
with a minimum 60-day notice requirement prior to the quarter-end. As of December 31, 2024 and 2023, no other
redemption restrictions or unfunded commitments exist for these investments.

Surviving Spouse Benefit It is assumed that 70% of males and 55% of females
have an eligible spouse, and that male participants are
three years older than their spouses and female
participants are one year younger than their spouses.
Benefit Limits Projected benefits are limited by the current IRC section
415 maximum benefit of $275,000.
Valuation of Plan Assets Smoothed fair market value of assets over the current
and prior two years, adjusted for contributions, benefit
payments, administrative expenses, and expected
earnings. The average value of assets calculated in this
manner is further limited to not less than 90% nor more
than 110% of fair market value.
A characteristic of this method is that the expected
distribution of the value of plan assets is skewed toward
understatement relative to the corresponding market
values for expected long-term rates of return in excess of
the third segment rate under IRC section 430(h)(2)(C)(iii).
Expected Return on Assets
2022 Plan Year 3.50%, limited to 5.92%
2023 Plan Year 5.25%, limited to 5.74%
2024 Plan Year 5.25%, limited to 5.59%
Trust Expenses Included in Target Normal Cost $7,000,000; prior year′s administrative expenses,
excluding PBGC premiums and increased by assumed
inflation of 2.30%, plus expected 2024 PBGC flat rate
and variable premiums, rounded to the nearest $100,000.
Actuarial Method Standard unit credit cost method
Valuation Date January 1, 2024

Schedule SB Attachment (Form 5500)—2024 Plan Year
HSBC North America (U.S.) Pension Plan
EIN: 23-2186091 PN: 001
Schedule SB, line 24—Change in Actuarial Assumptions
● A change in the cash balance interest crediting rate from 3.50% to 4.30% in order to better reflect
anticipated future experience.
● A change in the retirement rates for active and terminated vested participants to better reflect anticipated
future experience.
● A change in the optional payment form election rates for terminated vested participants to better reflect
anticipated future experience.
● Married percentage assumption for male participants changed from 65% of participants assumed to be
married with a spouse who is two years younger to 70% of participants assumed to be married with a
spouse who is three years younger.
Since the change in the non-prescribed assumption does not decrease the funding shortfall, approval of the
Commissioner is not required.
